title: Question 81

children: A 72-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of right facial drooping and burning pain on the right side of the tongue. He also reports a rash in the right ear. He reports no other medical problems and takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Vesicular and some crusted lesions are seen on the right external ear. Right facial palsy that includes the forehead is observed. Tongue findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a peripheral facial nerve palsy caused by varicella-zoster virus and is characterized by an erythematous vesicular rash on the ear (zoster oticus) or by lesions in the mouth, sometimes with tinnitus, hearing loss, nausea, vomiting, vertigo, or nystagmus.
The differential diagnosis of an infectious cause of peripheral facial nerve palsy includes herpes simplex virus type 1, Lyme disease, and varicella-zoster virus.
The most likely diagnosis for this older man is Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) caused by varicella-zoster virus (
Option D

). Ramsay Hunt syndrome is characterized by peripheral facial nerve palsy (cranial nerve VII) accompanied by an erythematous vesicular rash on the ear (zoster oticus) or lesions in the mouth. In this patient, the oral findings include mucosal erosions confined to the right side of the tongue. Patients may have tinnitus, hearing loss, nausea, vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus that can be explained by the involvement of the geniculate ganglion to the vestibulocochlear nerve within the bony facial canal. Differentiating between a peripheral and a central facial palsy is crucial because the latter is associated with an intracranial lesion. A peripheral facial palsy involves the whole side of the face, including the forehead, as in this patient. The differential diagnosis of an infectious cause of peripheral facial nerve (Bell) palsy includes herpes simplex virus type 1, Lyme disease caused by
Borrelia burgdorferi
, and varicella-zoster virus.
Infection of neurologic tissue occurs in approximately 15% of untreated patients with Lyme disease (
Option A

). Aseptic meningitis, peripheral nerve facial palsy (unilateral or bilateral), and radiculopathy may be present in isolation or associated with skin, musculoskeletal, or cardiac findings. When erythema migrans lesions are present, laboratory confirmation is unnecessary. Otherwise, two-tier serologic testing should be performed. However, Lyme disease would not present with vesicular lesions of the external ear and mucosal erosions confined to half of the tongue.
Herpes simplex virus type 1 (
Option B

) is the most common cause of Bell palsy, especially if the risk for Lyme disease is low. It is not associated with a vesicular rash of the external ear with mucosal lesions involving half the tongue.
Sarcoidosis (
Option C

) of the peripheral nerves can cause cranial neuropathies, including peripheral facial nerve palsy. Facial palsy may be unilateral or bilateral. The diagnosis is most apparent in patients with known sarcoidosis who develop neurologic findings but can be an elusive diagnosis in patients without known sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis would not be associated with the combination of vesicular and crusted skin lesions and mucosal erosions.

objective.__html: Diagnose Ramsay Hunt syndrome caused by herpes zoster infection.

references: Garro A, Nigrovic LE. Managing peripheral facial palsy. Ann Emerg Med. 2018;71:618-624.
